title: How to Use Pinking Shears

steps.headline: Sew your fabric's seam before you cut.
steps.description: Fabrics can only be pinked after the seam has been sewn. Depending on the fabric, you might use one of several seaming methods. You can use a sewing machine or hand-stitch the seam yourself.

steps.headline: Begin your cut along the edge of the seam.
steps.description: Don't take off too much of the fabric. Your fabric will fray least if it is as far from the seam itself as possible. While you can always cut off more if you're unsatisfied with the edge, you cannot put fabric back on after you've cut it.

steps.headline: Cut the seam in a straight line.
steps.description: Pinked hems look neat and tidy when cut in a straight line. If you have trouble keeping your scissors steady, use a ruler to measure your cut as you go. Make your way carefully through the fabric's edge to avoid wavering lines. Metal rulers are ideal for cutting in a straight line because they are harder to bend. You don't need to cut in a rush. Pink your fabric at your own pace.

steps.headline: Practice on a fabric swatch first.
steps.description: If this is your first time using pinking shears, buy extra fabric to experiment with before you make the actual cuts. Try cutting in straight lines and at different paces to find what works best with you.

steps.headline: Use pinking shears on fabrics only.
steps.description: Some specialized pinking shears are made for use on fabric as well as leather, paper, and other materials. In most cases, however, anything except fabric will dull your shears. To avoid having to sharpen your shears often, primarily cut fabric.

steps.headline: Pick pinking shears for fabrics with solid colors.
steps.description: Although you can use pinking shears on patterned fabrics, your project will not turn out as nicely. Look for fabrics in solid shades or very simple patterns. Your finished piece will look much more professional. Striped fabric looks especially poor when cut by pinking shears.

steps.headline: Try pinking shears on smooth fabrics.
steps.description: Crisp fabrics (like taffeta or chiffon) look clean when cut by pinking shears. This is because the ridge left over by the shears is less thick and because the shears don't have to cut through too many layers. Bulky fabrics are usually harder to cut in a straight line.

steps.headline: Cut primarily woven fabrics with pinking shears.
steps.description: Woven fabrics are those made by weaving threads over and under each other (hence the name). Tightly woven fabrics fray less and are best for pinking. Non-stretchy woven fabrics work particularly well if you want the cleanest cut. Examples of woven fabrics include: chiffon, denim, flannel, taffeta, crepe, kashmir silk, and chintz.

steps.headline: Sharpen your pinking shears periodically.
steps.description: Dull pinking shears will make frayed cuts. When your shears are dull, use a sharpening wheel or sandpaper to maintain your shears. For routine maintenance, sharpen your scissors every four to six months. Do not use aluminum foil to sharpen pinking shears, as this method is ineffective on the jagged edges.

steps.headline: Cut wax paper with your shears.
steps.description: Pinking shears cut well with some lubrication. If your shears are sharpened but still fray your fabric, try cutting a few rows of wax paper. Wax residue will transfer to the shears and make your scissors less prone to sticking.

steps.headline: Oil your pinking shears.
steps.description: On occasions where cutting wax paper does not keep your shears lubricated enough, clean your scissors with oil. Open your scissors and place a few drops on the pivot between the blades. Open and close your scissors several times, then wipe off residual oil with a dry cloth.

steps.headline: Keep an eye out for rust.
steps.description: Rusty pinking shears can make your fabric fray, even after cutting. If you spot any rust, rub it off vigorously using steel wool and dish soap. Dip your scissors in vinegar and scrub it clean, if your shears suffer from heavy rusting. If neither steel wool nor vinegar works, use WD-40 to scrub your rusty shears. Do not store your pinking shears in wet or moist places.

text: Cutting Fabric Sew your fabric's seam before you cut. Fabrics can only be pinked after the seam has been sewn. Depending on the fabric, you might use one of several seaming methods. You can use a sewing machine or hand-stitch the seam yourself. Begin your cut along the edge of the seam. Don't take off too much of the fabric. Your fabric will fray least if it is as far from the seam itself as possible. While you can always cut off more if you're unsatisfied with the edge, you cannot put fabric back on after you've cut it. Cut the seam in a straight line. Pinked hems look neat and tidy when cut in a straight line. If you have trouble keeping your scissors steady, use a ruler to measure your cut as you go. Make your way carefully through the fabric's edge to avoid wavering lines. Metal rulers are ideal for cutting in a straight line because they are harder to bend. You don't need to cut in a rush. Pink your fabric at your own pace. Practice on a fabric swatch first. If this is your first time using pinking shears, buy extra fabric to experiment with before you make the actual cuts. Try cutting in straight lines and at different paces to find what works best with you. Choosing the Right Material Use pinking shears on fabrics only. Some specialized pinking shears are made for use on fabric as well as leather, paper, and other materials. In most cases, however, anything except fabric will dull your shears. To avoid having to sharpen your shears often, primarily cut fabric. Pick pinking shears for fabrics with solid colors. Although you can use pinking shears on patterned fabrics, your project will not turn out as nicely. Look for fabrics in solid shades or very simple patterns. Your finished piece will look much more professional. Striped fabric looks especially poor when cut by pinking shears. Try pinking shears on smooth fabrics. Crisp fabrics (like taffeta or chiffon) look clean when cut by pinking shears. This is because the ridge left over by the shears is less thick and because the shears don't have to cut through too many layers. Bulky fabrics are usually harder to cut in a straight line. Cut primarily woven fabrics with pinking shears. Woven fabrics are those made by weaving threads over and under each other (hence the name). Tightly woven fabrics fray less and are best for pinking. Non-stretchy woven fabrics work particularly well if you want the cleanest cut. Examples of woven fabrics include: chiffon, denim, flannel, taffeta, crepe, kashmir silk, and chintz. Cleaning Pinking Shears Sharpen your pinking shears periodically. Dull pinking shears will make frayed cuts. When your shears are dull, use a sharpening wheel or sandpaper to maintain your shears. For routine maintenance, sharpen your scissors every four to six months. Do not use aluminum foil to sharpen pinking shears, as this method is ineffective on the jagged edges. Cut wax paper with your shears. Pinking shears cut well with some lubrication. If your shears are sharpened but still fray your fabric, try cutting a few rows of wax paper. Wax residue will transfer to the shears and make your scissors less prone to sticking. Oil your pinking shears. On occasions where cutting wax paper does not keep your shears lubricated enough, clean your scissors with oil. Open your scissors and place a few drops on the pivot between the blades. Open and close your scissors several times, then wipe off residual oil with a dry cloth. Keep an eye out for rust. Rusty pinking shears can make your fabric fray, even after cutting. If you spot any rust, rub it off vigorously using steel wool and dish soap. Dip your scissors in vinegar and scrub it clean, if your shears suffer from heavy rusting. If neither steel wool nor vinegar works, use WD-40 to scrub your rusty shears. Do not store your pinking shears in wet or moist places.

Bulky fabrics are usually harder to cut in a straight line.

Woven fabrics are those made by weaving threads over and under each other (hence the name).
